so we're kind of going in a medium level

is customers make assumptions about

the challenge with this is the virtual

you need to allocate for that compared

there are some benefits that people

with Amazon workspaces it's all highly
managed by somebody else so if you're
running a virtual desktop environment
like
VMware or Citrix or Terminal Services a

that cost justification of building

a zero client is basically just an

it has no operating system on it
whatsoever it has no ability to be
patched or updated it can't get a virus
it doesn't have any moving parts on it
and they're very inexpensive you can get

limited team so there's no second

POS supported zero clients so you can

the manufacturers have management
consoles so if you need to roll out

them they won't put antivirus on them
they won't put any sort of Active
Directory group policies in place to
control them and that's a mistake
because they're susceptible to the same
problems that a regular desktop would be
getting viruses having performance
issues monitoring you need to be able to
monitor performance on them and there
are some great tools that are out there
for monitoring the performance the
end-user performance of this virtual
desktop there are specific group policy
configuration settings for the PC IP
protocol
many people don't realize they exist but
you can control things like clipboard
copy/paste capabilities printer
remapping drive remapping and many other
functionality inside the group policy so
there are group policy specific settings
to the Amazon workspaces and even more
specific ones all the way down to the
zero clients the other thing that many
customers are considering and
implementing is multi-factor

secure desktop environment you're
enabling people to log in from anywhere
to work on any device and the benefit
there
great now now your people can work from
anywhere but how are you ensuring with a

really is who they are their credentials
haven't been stolen and there's many
different products on the market but one
of the things we see customers miss very
frequently is considering at least some
sort of multi-factor authentication and
there's many many vendors as I was
walking around here I saw supporting

it's important to roll it out and have
it as part of your plan during the

architected correctly and there's some
important considerations around if
you're using Xero clients how MFA
multi-factor authentication works and
mobility how what kind of tokens you're
using and that's important as well but
at the end of the day you need to treat
this just like a managed desktop and a

as an AR mm total remote remote
management and monitoring tool that

still need to treat them like a regular
regular desktop the other thing that we
believe is important in a mistake a lot
of customers make when they're deploying

using the native billing tools that are

give you some information there's some
basic cost exploring stuff that exists
in there but you can plug in third-party

detailed billing analytics information
about how your workspaces are being used
so as an example we were working with a

had 14 workspaces that were idle for 30
days
they just weren't even logged into for
30 days and that customer was paying for
those workspaces they had no idea that
nobody had logged into them from the
Amazon console side you see a workspace
with a user name on it but you don't
necessarily know that it's idle and
there could be a cost savings there so
it's really important to have some sort
of billing management tool or platform
that's external to Amazon
and they'll give you data about unused
or idled sessions bad logins the health
of your workspaces they're just starting
to expose some of the healthy unhealthy

of these third-party monitoring tools
are starting to pick them up which is
really important but whether or not you

of every month
that bill that bill hits your Amazon
usage unlike many other services in
Amazon you pay a hundred percent upfront
for that and not as you use it over the
month the other thing the billing tools
help you manage is by Department billing
so we had a use case where we had a
financial services customer and they
wanted to build back different locations
so they tagged each of their workspaces
by location and rolled it up to a bill
and now they can break out the bill for
those workspaces by location and
actually break out the cost of those
workspaces and build them back to a

again that's something you don't get

but being able to report on them
automatically as an external feature
picking the right bundle for the
workspaces workspaces are broken out
into several bundles they've just added
some new ones the controlling factor
here for most of the customers that we
see is RAM how are the applications on
those desktops going to utilize the the
RAM memory in the workspace that's
usually the deciding factor on what
workspace you're going to go to and
creating bundles around those but you
need to do extensive extensive testing
with your application set you know
someone says they use they use Excel how
are they using Excel are they using
giant data sets and really test that
because if you get this wrong on your
initial deployment and you roll it out
at scale you now have to unroll all
those bundles fix them and roll them all
back out again so it's really important
to size these correctly also as of
January they started deploying
solid-state drives inside the workspaces
and that was a new feature a lot of
customers were excited about it but one
of the most common misunderstandings was
if you didn't recreate your bundle and
redeploy that out to your clients you
didn't get those solid-state drives so
you had to actually tear down end-user
desktops and rebuild them
to get the the new functionality the

you guys will all figure it out by

someone who consistently does it over

where we can actually get funding from
